ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Music analysis Repertoire Historical context of Russian music
Multiple new skills, including structurising my analysis, theoretical knowledge, and etc.
Learned music, analytic, and historic literatures pertinent to the field.

I think most of all, I gained a thorough historical perspective on Russian music. Theoretically, the analytical techniques were familiar, but now I know which trends emerged when, and how they relate to one another.

I've got to know many useful resources for the topic I am passionate about. I benefited a lot from our class discussions and from how Prof. McCreless combined the historical and analytical aspects to understand the specificity of Russian music.
In this course, I learned a great deal about Russian music spanning 1830 to 1930. I also learned more about how to analyze and write about music in a way that is more precise and effective.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Music analysis assignments Engagement with music history and music theory concepts together Interesting course material
This is a very broad course, so more details, such as spending on particlular composer and his pieces would be great. Maybe, stretching this course in two would be a good idea.
The course was great and the music I learned in it was exceptional.
Enjoyed dong hands-on analysis most weeks. The reading load was heavy, but some weeks certain readings were only suggested if we had time, so it was fine.

Strengths: - Course materials and readings - Analysis combined both historical + musical-theoretical perspectives - Prof. McCreless's deep knowledge and involvement into the subject Weaknesses/possible improvements: - From the analytical perspective I think it would be worthy to actually dedicate maybe a 1/2 of a class to learning Russian/Chaikovsky way of the treatment of Secondary Dominant. I think this is the case when the theory led the practice. - It would be beneficial if student presentations would be more diverse. I felt like frequently the presentations were focused on the analysis harmony in a rather generic/obvious way. I'd love to hear more ideas connected to extra-musical/performance/historical/or somewhat unexpected aspects/points of view.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this course is helpful for anyone who wants to learn more about Russian music.
It may not be for everyone, but if you have an interest in Russian music, it's definitely a course to take.
Yes, I would; either to broaden or deepen the knowledge of the Russian music - this is a course of the high quality; therefore, it is definitely worth taking.
Yes, highly recommended. The professor is very good and the topic is fascinating.
